alternatives.transcript: Hi, I'm Jacques Pepin, and I'm cooking at home. When I cook lamb, you know, very often I look for lamb. Lamb chops are great. The best lamb chop for me is this 1. This is a shoulder lamb chop. See the bone of the shoulder here, the blade. For me, this is moister and more tender than the loin, even, and much less expensive. Sometimes there is more fat than it is here. I try to choose 1 with the least amount of fat. There is still some fat in the center. It's like the Boston butt that you have, you know, in the pork, the shoulder, makes a great roast. And it's the same dish here. So salt, pepper on top of this. Of course, I often grill it, but here we're sautéing it in a skillet. I'm gonna put a, like, half a tablespoon of oil, you know I call it oil, with the same amount of butter. We're gonna saute that. Of course I like it medium rare in the center. So that's gonna cook for a few minutes, couple of minutes here. Going to lower the heat a little bit. And I'm gonna put a garnish of mushroom. I have those mushroom here. A little old from my refrigerator, so they need washing. It is a fallacy that you cannot wash mushroom. Of course you wash mushroom. The point is that you don't do it ahead. You wash mushroom and you use them as fast as you can after. I have 2 large mushroom that I'm going to put, cook gently all around here. So that's gonna cook a couple of minutes on this side, couple of minutes on the other side. So now it's about 3 minutes. Turn my lunch up here. The mushroom too. We'll cook it another 2, 3 minutes on this side as well. Dash of salt on the mushrooms. And maybe I put a little bit of garlic at the end. I have a nice slice of garlic. And maybe I will just do some slice of garlic like this, and I will add them at the end. See another 3 minutes on each side. I can touch it like that and I know it's still pretty rare, but good, now it has to rest. I'm putting my garlic in there now. A little slice of garlic. Just close. I'm shutting off the heat. So it's just off the heat now. And I leave it here. I'm going to cover it. And maybe 3, 4, 5 minutes. The point is I don't want it to get cold. But also, when the meat cooked, it shrank like this. And all the juice got toward the center on the other side. So when the meat is finished cooking, You have to let it rest a little bit. So the meat decontract. It was contracted when it cooked. It decontracts, and the juice run through it. And it's pink from the beginning to the end. Otherwise, you end up with the outside, which is kind of gray, overcooked, and the inside, which is almost raw. So the resting is important on something like that, 345 minutes, on a steak, on a rack of lamb, like 8, 10 minutes, and a standing rib roast, like 30, 45 minutes. Okay, I think it rested long enough now. We can see that when it's red, the juice come out of it. Whoop. I have my garnish here. See the juice released. It's released a fair amount of juice. A mushroom here. That's a nice garnish. And you feel the natural juice, the leaf layer of garlic. That's it. Of course a bit of green on top of it. Always finish. That's it. Should be rested. So, can see cut right in the center. It's going to be beautifully medium rare, just the way I like it. Of course, if you like it longer, or you cook it longer, if you like it more cooked. And this is it, the lamb shoulder with mushroom sauté. Happy cooking. ♪♪

paragraphs.transcript:
Hi, I'm Jacques Pepin, and I'm cooking at home. When I cook lamb, you know, very often I look for lamb. Lamb chops are great. The best lamb chop for me is this 1. This is a shoulder lamb chop.

See the bone of the shoulder here, the blade. For me, this is moister and more tender than the loin, even, and much less expensive. Sometimes there is more fat than it is here. I try to choose 1 with the least amount of fat. There is still some fat in the center.

It's like the Boston butt that you have, you know, in the pork, the shoulder, makes a great roast. And it's the same dish here. So salt, pepper on top of this. Of course, I often grill it, but here we're sautéing it in a skillet. I'm gonna put a, like, half a tablespoon of oil, you know I call it oil, with the same amount of butter.

We're gonna saute that. Of course I like it medium rare in the center. So that's gonna cook for a few minutes, couple of minutes here. Going to lower the heat a little bit. And I'm gonna put a garnish of mushroom.

I have those mushroom here. A little old from my refrigerator, so they need washing. It is a fallacy that you cannot wash mushroom. Of course you wash mushroom. The point is that you don't do it ahead.

You wash mushroom and you use them as fast as you can after. I have 2 large mushroom that I'm going to put, cook gently all around here. So that's gonna cook a couple of minutes on this side, couple of minutes on the other side. So now it's about 3 minutes. Turn my lunch up here.

The mushroom too. We'll cook it another 2, 3 minutes on this side as well. Dash of salt on the mushrooms. And maybe I put a little bit of garlic at the end. I have a nice slice of garlic.

And maybe I will just do some slice of garlic like this, and I will add them at the end. See another 3 minutes on each side. I can touch it like that and I know it's still pretty rare, but good, now it has to rest. I'm putting my garlic in there now. A little slice of garlic.

Just close. I'm shutting off the heat. So it's just off the heat now. And I leave it here. I'm going to cover it.

And maybe 3, 4, 5 minutes. The point is I don't want it to get cold. But also, when the meat cooked, it shrank like this. And all the juice got toward the center on the other side. So when the meat is finished cooking, You have to let it rest a little bit.

So the meat decontract. It was contracted when it cooked. It decontracts, and the juice run through it. And it's pink from the beginning to the end. Otherwise, you end up with the outside, which is kind of gray, overcooked, and the inside, which is almost raw.

So the resting is important on something like that, 345 minutes, on a steak, on a rack of lamb, like 8, 10 minutes, and a standing rib roast, like 30, 45 minutes. Okay, I think it rested long enough now. We can see that when it's red, the juice come out of it. Whoop. I have my garnish here.

See the juice released. It's released a fair amount of juice. A mushroom here. That's a nice garnish. And you feel the natural juice, the leaf layer of garlic.

That's it. Of course a bit of green on top of it. Always finish. That's it. Should be rested.

So, can see cut right in the center. It's going to be beautifully medium rare, just the way I like it. Of course, if you like it longer, or you cook it longer, if you like it more cooked. And this is it, the lamb shoulder with mushroom sauté. Happy cooking.

♪♪
